awd_titl_txt: Wireless Imaging Intensity Interferometer for Astronomy
awd_abstract_narration:
Two or more telescopes that work as one can in principle make extremely precise measurements of distances and angles. This project will extend the capabilities of the Southern Connecticut Stellar Interferometer (SCSI), a two-telescope instrument that can measure the sizes of bright stars. Because SCSI is based on a different method than most multi-telescope instruments in use today, the science that is enabled by the project will be different than what has been done in the field to date. For example, SCSI can easily observe in blue light, a wavelength range in which it is harder for other existing instruments to be efficient due to the effects of turbulence in the air. The project will also provide for the training of physics students and public observing events at Southern Connecticut State University.

SCSI yields extremely high-resolution information about stars by precisely timing the arrival of photons at each telescope station and comparing the data streams after the fact, a technique known as intensity interferometry.  The project will yield three significant improvements to SCSI. First, it will increase the number of telescopes used from two to three, something that is necessary in order to go beyond measurements of stellar size and obtain a true imaging capability. Second, new electronics will be used to attempt to demonstrate that the instrument can be successfully used in a wireless mode. If this is achieved, then the distance between the three telescope stations can be increased dramatically, leading to the capability for obtaining much finer image detail. Third, the sensitivity of the instrument will be significantly improved by using more detectors and increasing the amount of light that can be collected. Fainter stars will therefore be successfully observed. The education and public outreach enabled by the award will help serve the need for highly-educated, research-capable science and engineering professionals in Connecticut and the Northeast and stimulate interest in science both among K-12 students and the general public in the New Haven community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Two or more telescopes that work as one can in principle make ultra-precise measurements of the angular sizes of astronomical objects. This project was undertaken to extend the capabilities of the Southern Connecticut Stellar Interferometer (SCSI), which was originally a two-telescope instrument that can measure the diameters of bright stars. Because SCSI is based on a different method than most multi-telescope instruments in use today, the science that is enabled by the project is different from and complementary to what has been done in the field to date. For example, SCSI can easily observe in blue light, a wavelength range in which it is harder for other existing instruments to be efficient due to the effects of turbulence in the air.

SCSI yields extremely high-resolution information about stars by precisely timing the arrival of individual photons at each telescope station and comparing the data streams after the fact, a technique known as intensity interferometry. The project enabled three significant improvements to SCSI. First, it increased the number of telescopes used from two to three, something that is necessary in order to go beyond measurements of stellar size and obtain a true imaging capability. An image of the three-telescope system is attached here. Second, new electronics were integrated into the system to attempt to demonstrate that the instrument can be successfully used in a wireless mode. This allows the distance between the three telescope stations to be increased dramatically, leading to the capability for obtaining much finer image detail. Third, the sensitivity of the instrument was improved by increasing the amount of light that can be collected. Fainter and in some cases more distant stars can now be observed. These changes to SCSI now put it on the threshold of being a working observatory for measuring the properties of stars at high precision.

The education and public outreach enabled by the award helped to serve the need for highly-educated, research-capable science and engineering professionals in Connecticut and the Northeast. Four students in the Master's program in Applied Physics as well as two undergraduate Physics majors at Southern Connecticut State University (SCSU) worked on the project during the course of the award. Of those who have graduated, one is teaching at the college level and another received a paid internship in an optics company in Connecticut, based partly on their work on this project. In terms of outreach, the SCSU planetarium was also brought back to a usable condition for public outreach events, and several planetarium shows were given in order to stimulate interest in science both among K-12 students and the general public in the New Haven area. SCSU is now in the position to use the planetarium as an outreach tool to the community, helping to interest K-12 students in pursing the STEM disciplines.
